conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your message and your interest in School_A.

When capacity is tight, we tend to differentiate candidates based on (1) overall academic readiness for our coursework, (2) sustained commitment/impact in a few activities (rather than many light involvements), and (3) clear fit—i.e., specific reasons our programs/community match what you want to pursue.

If you’d like us to evaluate you quickly this round, the most helpful information is:
- Your strongest academic indicators (recent grades/course rigor or equivalent)
- 1–2 activities where you’ve had meaningful responsibility or measurable impact
- A brief note on what you would engage in at School_A (specific clubs/programs/academic interests)

If School_A is a place you would commit to if admitted, you’re welcome to submit an [APPLY] at any time.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for applying again and for your continued willingness to commit to School_C.

At this time, we are not able to offer you admission, because we must continue to reserve our remaining seat in line with our selection priorities in case a higher-priority student applies in a later round.

On your question about a cutoff: we do not have a fixed public round number when we automatically stop holding the seat. In general, we only move to fill the seat with the best available committed applicant once it becomes clear that no higher-priority candidates are likely to enter our pool before the process ends. If you remain unmatched, you are welcome to keep applying in later rounds; if the seat is still open and we are no longer expecting higher-priority applicants, we will re-evaluate immediately.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority is D > E > A > B > C. Student_B is acceptable but low relative to remaining higher-priority candidates (D/E/A) who could still apply later. Since the game can run to round 30, it is strategically better for School_C to continue holding the seat for a higher-priority student rather than lock in B at round 10. Student_B asks for a cutoff condition; we should not commit to a specific round, but can give a general policy (e.g., near the end we may fill if still vacant) while still rejecting this apply per priorities.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for applying again and for your continued willingness to commit.

[REJECT] At this time, we are still not able to offer you admission because we must continue to reserve our remaining seat in line with our selection priorities.

On your question about a specific condition: we do not use a fixed “X rounds with no higher-priority applicants” rule. Instead, we reassess based on whether higher-priority students (in particular those ranked above you on our list) still have a realistic path to becoming unmatched and applying to School_C as the process continues. When it becomes clear—typically closer to the end of the process—that those higher-priority candidates are already placed elsewhere or are no longer likely to enter our pool, we will then move to fill the seat with the best available committed applicant.

If you remain unmatched, you are welcome to apply again in later rounds; we will re-evaluate immediately each time.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

However, by Round 12 School_C is the only school still open, implying other schools are likely filled and most students are likely matched or cycling. From preferences: D’s 3rd choice is School_C (after D, B), E’s 3rd choice is School_C (after D, E), A’s last choice is School_C, so A is very unlikely to apply; D/E could apply if rejected elsewhere, but with School_D’s priorities (B > D > E > C > A) and D/E ranking School_D first, they likely secured placements earlier. Given prolonged absence of higher-priority applicants to School_C across many rounds and the risk of ending unmatched (which is worse than taking B, since B is on the acceptable list), it is now optimal to accept Student_B to fill quota with the best available committed applicant.
